abstracts.cdata!:
The past decade in Albania has been
            characterized by very rapid economic growth and substantial
            improvements in the welfare of the population. Once labeled
            as the continent's poorest country, Albania has enjoyed
            annual real economic growth rates of around 6 percent over
            the last decade, enabling it to graduate from the
            Bank's concessional lending arm (the International
            Development Association or IDA) and to join the ranks of the
            world's upper-middle income countries. In July 2010,
            Albania's gross domestic product (GDP) per capita stood
            at United States (U.S.) $3,836, well above the IDA
            threshold. The last decade also saw important gains in the
            populations welfare evidenced by falling poverty rates and
            substantially improved millennium development goal (MDG)
            indicators. The Albanian economy has proven quite resilient
            in the face of domestic and exogenous shocks - for example,
            it was only one of two countries in Europe to achieve
            positive (albeit reduced) growth in the wake of the
            2008-2009 global financial and economic crisis.
